appendix.title: Dir
appendix.para: ArrayDir[]array ArrayDir[]string Passes its arguments to Dir.glob, returning the result.

Object or 0Dir.chdirdirectory=ENV['HOME'] || ENV['LOGDIR']{|directory| } Changes the current working directory of the process to directory and returns 0. If a block is supplied, it receives the new working directory as an argument and ensures the original working directory is restored when the block exits; the return value is that of the block. However, it is an error for multiple threads to have these blocks open simultaneously. If directory does not exist the appropriate Errno:: exception is raised.
0Dir.chrootdirectory Changes the root directory of the process—assuming it has the appropriate privileges—to directory. A NotImplementedError is raised on platforms without the chroot(2) system call.
0Dir.deletedirectory Deletes the empty directory directory, raising an Errno:: exception on error. Aliased to Dir.rmdir and Dir.unlink.
ArrayDir.entriesdirectory Returns the entries—filenames, ., and ..—of directory as an Array of Strings. Raises an Errno:: exception if the directory doesn’t exist.
true or falseDir.exist?directory Returns true if directory exists and is a directory; false, otherwise. Aliased by Dir.exists? and File.directory?.
true or falseDir.exists?directory Aliases Dir.exist?.
Enumerator or nilDir.foreach{|entry| } Yields each entry—filenames, ., and ..—of directory to the given block; returns an Enumerator if the block is omitted.
StringDir.getwd Returns the canonical path of the current working directory for this process. Aliased by Dir.pwd.

Array or falseDir.globpatternflags=0{|filename| } Yields the filenames matching the glob pattern pattern to the block; returning an Array if the block is omitted. The syntax of pattern and valid flags are explained in .
0Dir.mkdirdirectorypermissions Creates a directory named directory with the permissions given in permissions. The permissions are ignored on Windows, and modified by the current process’s umask.

DirDir.newdirectoryencoding: encoding Instantiates and returns a Dir object representing the directory named directory. The directory is assumed to have the same encoding as the local file system—i.e. Encoding.find('filesystem')—but an alternative encoding can be specified as encoding.

Dir or ObjectDir.opendirectoryencoding: encoding{|dir| } Behaves as Dir.new, but if a block is supplied the new Dir object is yielded to it, then closed when the block exits. Returns the value of the block, if one was given, or the new Dir object.
StringDir.pwd Aliases Dir.getwd.
0Dir.rmdirdirectory Aliases Dir.delete.
0Dir.unlinkdirectory Aliases Dir.delete.
nilDir#close Closes the directory stream represented by the receiver.
Enumerator or DirDir#each{|entry| } Yields each entry—filenames, ., and ..—of the receiver’s directory stream to the block, then returns self. Returns an Enumerator if the block is omitted.
StringDir#path Returns the path of the directory stream represented by the receiver.
IntegerDir#pos Returns the current position in the directory stream represented by the receiver. Aliased by Dir#tell.
IntegerDir#pos=position Seeks the receiver’s directory stream to the given position—which should have previously been returned by Dir#pos—then returns position.
String or nilDir#read Returns the next entry in the receiver’s stream, then advances the stream’s position. Returns nil after the last entry.
DirDir#rewind Resets the position of the receiver’s directory stream to its beginning, returning self.
IntegerDir#seekposition Seeks the receiver’s directory stream to the given position—which should have previously been returned by Dir#pos—then returns self.
IntegerDir#tell Aliases Dir#pos.
